metadata.titleEn: Spatially extensive long-term quality-assured land-atmosphere interactions dataset over the Tibetan Plateau
metadata.description: This dataset integrates comprehensive hourly observations of land-atmosphere interactions from 12 field observation stations on the Tibetan Plateau during the period of 2005 to 2021, including multi-layer meteorological data, multi-layer soil data, and turbulence data. The 12 field observation stations are the National Observation and Research Station for Qomolangma Special Atmospheric Processes and Environmental Changes (QOMS), the South-East Tibetan Plateau Station for integrated observation and research of alpine environment (SETORS), the Tibet Nam Co High-cold-lake and Environmental National Observation and Research Station (NAMORS), the Ngari Station for Desert Environment Observation and Research (NASED), the Muztagh Ata Westerly Observation and Research Station (MAWORS), Ngoring_Lake, Maqu, and TGL, Dashalong, Arou, Yakou, and Jingyangling Station. The multilayer meteorological data include wind speed, wind direction, air temperature, humidity, air pressure, and four components of radiation fluxes; the multilayer soil data include soil temperature and soil moisture; and the turbulence data include sensible heat flux and latent heat flux. Meanwhile, in view of the actual problems existing in the field observation data on the Tibetan Plateau, a data quality control program has been developed for different elements of each station, and a comprehensive field observation data processing system has been constructed. All observation elements have undergone a strict data quality control processes and  provided data quality control codes (0: correct data, 1: suspicious data, 2: incorrect data, 4: gap-filled data, 8: missing data, 9: not subjected to data quality control). This data can be widely applied in the analysis of meteorological element characteristics, evaluation of remote sensing product, development of remote sensing inversion algorithms, and evaluation and development of numerical simulations on the Tibetan Plateau.
metadata.instructions: This dataset file includes meteorological data (Met), soil data (Soil), and turbulence data (Flux), providing hourly observation data (Level0) and data products that have undergone data quality control (Level1). The naming convention for Level0 data files is: data type_ Site Name_ Year. csv, Level1 data file naming convention is QC_ Data type_ Site Name_ Year. csv. At the same time, the dataset also provides monthly data integrity and correct data proportion for each element at each site. The naming rule for data integrity files is: data type_ Site Name_ Avail.csv, where a value of 100 indicates that there are no missing observational data for this element in that month.

background: The Tibetan Plateau (TP) plays a critical role in influencing regional and global climate, via both thermal and dynamical mechanisms. Moreover, the TP has the most extensive high-elevation distribution of cryosphere outside the polar regions. Numerous research indicates that the TP plays an essential role in controlling regional and global climate through its thermal and mechanical mechanisms. Meanwhile, the TP is highly sensitive to climate change. Land–atmosphere interactions over the TP play a crucial role in controlling the hemispheric atmospheric circulation pattern and climate evolution. However, compared with other terrestrial regions of the world, observational data are scarce over the TP, owing to its vast geographic area with steep terrain, varied landforms, complex and diverse climates, and harsh environmental conditions. The sparse and biased spatial distribution of observation stations makes it difficult to match the high degree of landscape heterogeneity over the TP. Therefore, it is essential to improve the atmospheric observation capability on the TP and its surrounding areas and obtain accurate atmospheric physical parameters for the near-surface and boundary layers over the TP, which can significantly contribute to the scientific understanding of the weather, climate and environmental changes, as well as their impacts, from regional scale (TP) to global scale.
research objective: This paper presents a long-term (2005–2016) in situ observational dataset of hourly land–atmosphere interaction observations from an integrated high-elevation and cold-region observation network, composed of six field stations on the TP. The release of these continuous and long-term datasets with hourly resolution represents a leap forward in scientific data sharing across the TP, and it has been partially used in the past to assist in understanding key land surface processes. This dataset is described here comprehensively for facilitating a broader multidisciplinary community by enabling the evaluation and development of existing or new remote sensing algorithms as well as geophysical models for climate research and forecasting.
challenges: However, meteorological stations are biased and sparsely distributed over the TP, owing to the harsh environmental conditions, high elevations, complex topography and heterogeneous surfaces. Moreover, due to the weak representation of the stations, atmospheric conditions and the local land–atmosphere coupled system over the TP as well as its effects on surrounding regions are poorly quantified. The sparse and biased spatial distribution of observation stations makes it difficult to match the high degree of landscape heterogeneity over the TP. In addition, high uncertainties in the satellite-retrieved land and atmospheric environmental variables of the TP impair the establishment of continuous, long-term regional-scale observations in remote areas of the TP. The lack of sufficient observational data limits our understanding of the interactions between the different earth spheres with heterogeneous land surface conditions and hinders the development of parameterization schemes in some critical physical processes of the land surface and atmospheric boundary layer, thereby leading to associated uncertainties in estimating the past, present and future climate change and its impacts.
dataset: This paper presents a long-term (2005–2016) in situ observational dataset of hourly land–atmosphere interaction observations from an integrated high-elevation and cold-region observation network, composed of six field stations on the TP. These in situ observations contain both meteorological and micrometeorological measurements including gradient meteorology, surface radiation, eddy covariance (EC), soil temperature and soil water content profiles. Meteorological data were monitored by automatic weather stations (AWSs) or planetary boundary layer (PBL) observation systems. Multilayer soil temperature and moisture were recorded to capture vertical hydrothermal variations and the soil freeze–thaw process. In addition, an EC system consisting of an ultrasonic anemometer and an infrared gas analyzer was installed at each station to capture the high-frequency vertical exchanges of energy, momentum, water vapor and carbon dioxide within the atmospheric boundary layer.

Definition.Question: How are 'data quality control codes' utilized in datasets related to atmospheric observations on the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: Data quality control codes are a system used to categorize the integrity of observational data collected from various stations. These codes help identify the status of the data: 0 for correct data, 1 for suspicious data, 2 for erroneous data, 4 for interpolated data, 8 for missing data, and 9 for data not yet quality-controlled, ensuring the dataset's reliability for research and applications.

Definition.Question: What is the role of 'eddy covariance (EC) systems' in collecting data over the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: Eddy covariance (EC) systems are used to measure high-frequency vertical exchanges of energy, momentum, water vapor, and carbon dioxide within the atmospheric boundary layer. This involves the use of an ultrasonic anemometer and an infrared gas analyzer to capture these exchanges, providing crucial data for understanding land–atmosphere interactions in high-elevation and cold-region environments like the Tibetan Plateau.

Comparison.Question: How do the data quality control methods applied to land-atmosphere interaction datasets on the Tibetan Plateau compare to general data quality control strategies used in other remote and harsh environments?
Comparison.Answer: The dataset from the Tibetan Plateau uses a detailed quality control scheme with codes indicating data status, such as correct, suspicious, erroneous, interpolated, missing, or uncontrolled data. This approach is tailored to address the unique challenges posed by the Plateau's complex and diverse climates, steep terrain, and sparse station distribution. In other remote environments, data quality control methods may also consider local environmental conditions but might not have such a comprehensive coding system due to different operational constraints and technological capabilities.

Interpretation.Question: What implications do the data quality control measures have on the interpretation of observational data collected from the Tibetan Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: Data quality control measures, such as coding for data accuracy (0: correct data, 1: questionable data, etc.), are crucial for ensuring the reliability of observational data. These measures help address issues of data accuracy and completeness, which are critical for interpreting land-atmosphere interactions and understanding climate processes over the Tibetan Plateau. They enable researchers to assess the credibility of the data before using it for further analysis or model development.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps for capturing vertical hydrothermal variations and the soil freeze–thaw process in the Tibetan Plateau using multilayer soil data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To capture vertical hydrothermal variations and the soil freeze–thaw process in the Tibetan Plateau, multilayer soil data is recorded by installing sensors that measure soil temperature and moisture at different depths. This allows for continuous monitoring of changes across multiple soil layers, providing insights into the vertical distribution of thermal and moisture conditions over time.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the collection of hourly land-atmosphere interaction data in high-elevation and cold regions?
Enablement.Answer: The use of automatic weather stations (AWSs), planetary boundary layer (PBL) observation systems, and eddy covariance (EC) systems have enabled the collection of hourly land-atmosphere interaction data in high-elevation and cold regions. These technologies allow for continuous and precise measurement of meteorological and micrometeorological variables, including gradient meteorology, surface radiation, energy exchanges, and soil temperature profiles.

This includes gradient meteorology, surface radiation, energy exchanges, and soil temperature and moisture profiles, facilitating a detailed understanding of land-atmosphere interactions over the Tibetan Plateau.

These systems must be robust enough to operate in harsh environmental conditions, ensuring reliable data collection despite the challenging terrain and climate.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore and summarize the challenges associated with data collection over the Tibetan Plateau and how these challenges impact the accuracy of atmospheric measurements.
Request/Directive.Answer: The Tibetan Plateau faces challenges in data collection due to harsh environmental conditions, high elevations, complex topography, and heterogeneous surfaces, leading to a sparse and biased spatial distribution of meteorological stations. These factors impair the accurate quantification of atmospheric conditions and the local land–atmosphere coupled system, resulting in high uncertainties in satellite-retrieved land and atmospheric variables. This scarcity of data limits understanding of earth sphere interactions and hinders the development of critical parameterization schemes, ultimately affecting the estimation of climate change impacts.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an overview of the data collection methods used to monitor land–atmosphere interactions on the Tibetan Plateau, highlighting the technologies involved.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data collection methods on the Tibetan Plateau for land–atmosphere interactions involve in situ observational datasets with hourly resolution from field stations. These methods include automatic weather stations (AWSs) or planetary boundary layer (PBL) observation systems for meteorological data, and multilayer soil temperature and moisture recordings for capturing vertical hydrothermal variations. Additionally, an eddy covariance (EC) system, consisting of an ultrasonic anemometer and an infrared gas analyzer, is used to capture high-frequency vertical exchanges of energy, momentum, water vapor, and carbon dioxide within the atmospheric boundary layer.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the potential benefits of improving the spatial distribution of observation stations on the Tibetan Plateau and how this could enhance climate research and forecasting.
Request/Directive.Answer: Improving the spatial distribution of observation stations on the Tibetan Plateau would provide a more comprehensive dataset, allowing for better representation of the diverse and heterogeneous landscapes. This enhancement in data coverage would reduce uncertainties in satellite-retrieved variables and improve the understanding of land–atmosphere interactions. Consequently, it would facilitate the development of more accurate parameterization schemes, resulting in better climate models and forecasts. It would also enable a deeper scientific understanding of the weather, climate, and environmental changes from regional to global scales.
